results.headline: Nature Provides Solace for a Writer Who Wrestles With Being Disabled

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Planet of Snail

results.summary_short: In the South Korean documentary “Planet of Snail” the young protagonist, who is deaf and blind, compares his sense of isolation to being an astronaut adrift in space.

results.headline: Let Them Eat Crow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Queen of Versailles

results.summary_short: “The Queen of Versailles” follows a high-living couple as they seek to build the largest private home in America just as the 2008 financial crisis hits.

results.headline: Courted by 2 Suitors in a Pastoral

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Well Digger's Daughter

results.summary_short: Daniel Auteuil directs and stars in a remake of a 1940 rural melodrama by Marcel Pagnol. The new version also stars Astrid Bergès-Frisbey.

results.headline: Violent, Yes, but a Story Driven by Emotion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai

results.summary_short: In Takashi Miike’s “Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai,” a samurai cast adrift arrives at the estate of a feudal lord, requesting permission to commit ritual suicide in the courtyard.

results.headline: A Manhattan Roundelay of Young, Mating Singles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 30 Beats

results.summary_short: Alexis Lloyd’s “30 Beats” is an erotic tone poem to contemporary New York that observes the mating rituals of youngish singles with time and money to play.

results.headline: A Rejected Superhero Ends Up at Ground Zero

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dark Knight Rises

results.summary_short: Christopher Nolan’s “Dark Knight Rises” wraps up his post-Sept. 11 epic of ambivalent good vs. multidimensional evil with a burst of light.

results.headline: Production’s Wagnerian Difficulties

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wagner's Dream

results.summary_short: “Wagner’s Dream,” directed by Susan Froemke, is a documentary that gives a behind-the-scenes look at the making of Robert Lepage’s staging of the four-part “Ring” cycle for the Metropolitan Opera.

results.headline: Rural Life Seen Through a Man Who Has Lived Many Seasons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lung Neaw Visits His Neighbors

results.summary_short: Time slows to a crawl in “Lung Neaw Visits His Neighbors,” the first feature by the Argentine-born, New York-based Thai artist, Rirkrit Tiravanija.

results.headline: Missing Child Seems Found, but His Family Is at a Loss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Imposter

results.summary_short: Bart Layton’s documentary “The Imposter” lays out the strange tale of a French con artist who was accepted by a Texas family as its missing teenage son.

results.headline: The Seedy Betting Parlor Where Dreams Go to Die

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ponies

results.summary_short: “Ponies” involves the interactions of three immigrants from different continents who converge at a ratty New York City betting parlor.

results.headline: As the Bastille Falls, Gossip in Versailles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Farewell, My Queen

results.summary_short: Benoît Jacquot’s look at three days in the life and lies of a doomed monarch presents Marie Antoinette, Versailles and the fall of the Bastille, from the perspective of servants.

results.headline: Baseball Dreams and Schemes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ballplayer Pelotero

results.summary_short: Ballplayer: Pelotero” is a stark documentary that examines the process of scouting young baseball players in the Dominican Republic.

results.headline: A Reunion of Two Sisters; One Is Refined, One Isn’t

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Union Square

results.summary_short: Nancy Savoca’s “Union Square” is the tale of two sisters, played by Mira Sorvino and Tammy Blanchard, divided by temperament, geography and class.

results.headline: A Little Bollywood Flavors This ‘Tess’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trishna

results.summary_short: In “Trishna” Michael Winterbottom takes on Thomas Hardy’s “Tess of the D’Urbervilles.”

results.headline: The Chatty Cathys of the Prehistoric World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ice Age: Continental Drift

results.summary_short: “Ice Age: Continental Drift” has antic animation and celebrity voices (Nicki Minaj and Drake as mammoths, for example) that never seem to stop talking.

results.headline: Male Psychic Meets Female Ghostbusters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Lights

results.summary_short: “Red Lights” stars Robert De Niro as a blind psychic, and Sigourney Weaver and Cillian Murphy as skeptical scientists who investigate paranormal events.

results.headline: Exploring Every Corner of a Remote Port of Call
results.display_title: It's the Earth Not the Moon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's the Earth Not the Moon

results.summary_short: “It’s the Earth Not the Moon” is a three-hour voyage to Corvo, the smallest and northernmost island in the Azores, on Europe’s western edge.

results.headline: A Countercultural Civics Comedy: Hotheaded Upstart vs. Polished Incumbent

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grassroots

results.summary_short: “Grassroots” is a true David and Goliath story in which a naïve candidate for Seattle City Council goes up against an entrenched incumbent.

results.headline: Challenges of Marriage in 1880s Palestine

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valley of Strength

results.summary_short: “Gei Oni” (“Valley of Strength”), set in the late 19th century, tells the story of a young Jewish couple facing the arduous challenges of settlement in Palestine.

results.headline: Fostering Mixed-Race Children in Ukraine
results.display_title: Family Portrait in Black and White

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Family Portrait in Black and White

results.summary_short: “Family Portrait in Black and White” portrays a woman in Ukraine and the more than 20 adopted and foster children she has taken in.
